Description: Terracotta conical stamp, hand-modelled in Nile clay with incised anthemion.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The stamp, probable used in a pottery workshop at Naukratis, can be compared with stamps used in Aswan workshop for the production of stamped late Roman red-ware bowls, Egyptian Red Slip A Ware (Bailey 2008, 160, nos 3596-9). This stamp, however, was used for ealier ceramic production, probably Ptolemaic black-slipped ware, which can bear a stamped decoration of palmette or anthemion. For another possible pottery stamp from Naukratis: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.668. Bailey, D.M. 2008, Catalogue of the Terracottas in the British Museum 4: Ptolemaic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, London.
Probably from a pottery workshop of late Classical or Ptolemaic date.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (PA.15)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4876 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
